newsitem.title: USA: Muni yields rise slightly in past week - Delphis.
newsitem.headline: Muni yields rise slightly in past week - Delphis.

text.p: Municipal bond yields rose about five basis points in the week ended Thursday, though the triple-A sector managed for the most part to hold steady, Delphis Hanover Corp said Friday.
The market's losses roughly mirrored the Treasury market, where the yield on the long bond rose three basis points, to 6.84 percent, over the same period.
A stronger-than-expected durable goods report Friday morning sent yields surging again, with the long bond hitting 6.94 percent by mid-afternoon.
Thirty-year Aaa-rated municipal yields where unchanged for the second week in a row, at 5.60 percent, Delphis said. Thirty-year Baa yields rose five basis points to 6.35 percent.
In the intermediate sector, ten-year Aaa-rated muni yields were unchanged at 4.85 percent, while Baa-rated 10-years rose five to 5.65 percent.
Average yields on one-year municipal bonds were up five basis points across the credit spectrum, with Aaa's at 3.65 percent and Baa-rated one-years moving to 4.40 percent.

The Aaa municipal yield curve flattened five basis points to 195 basis points, reversing the prior week's five basis point steepening. The spread between one-year and 30-year Baa's was unchanged at 195.
The credit spread between Aaa-rated and Baa-rated one-years was unchanged at 75 basis points, and the 30-year spread widened five to 75 basis points.
